p: Although the decentralization of disease control has allowed the municipality to expand its actions, the control and prevention of infectious diseases heavily relies on mandatory notification issued in the Notifiable Disease Surveillance System (SINAN) [ 29]. Thus, work in this field depends on constant case notification and investigation, data transmission to other levels, and the construction of databases and information systems [ 34]. The compartmentalization of surveillance has impaired necessary integration with networks within the Unified Health System (SUS), which results in limited response to local needs and problems [ 9, 24].
